description: The Managing macOS Servers series is designed to demonstrate how to use and deploy the macOS server app in a production environment. It covers installation, configuration and maintenance of the various services that make up the macOS server app. In addition, the series covers alternate services that can be used as replacements to services that are no longer supported natively by Apple.
descriptionMD: The Managing macOS Servers series is designed to demonstrate how to use and deploy the macOS server app in a production environment. It covers installation, configuration and maintenance of the various services that make up the macOS server app. In addition, the series covers alternate services that can be used as replacements to services that are no longer supported natively by Apple.
name: Managing macOS Servers 10.13
subtitle: macOS Server

episodes.description: The Managing macOS Servers series is designed to demonstrate how to use and deploy the macOS server app in a production environment. It covers installation, configuration and maintenance of the various services that make up the macOS server app. In addition, the series covers alternate services that can be used as replacements to services that are no longer supported natively by Apple.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.028
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.135 --> 00:00:07.260
Hello, thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:07.260 --> 00:00:12.055
We're talking about managing macOS Server
10.13, a new course with Don Pezet.

4
00:00:12.055 --> 00:00:15.285
Don, can you tell us
what the course is about?

5
00:00:15.285 --> 00:00:16.098
>> Absolutely,

6
00:00:16.098 --> 00:00:19.889
most of us know macOS as a desktop
operating system that we can run on

7
00:00:19.889 --> 00:00:23.290
laptops, and iMacs, Mac Minis,
and all that good stuff.

8
00:00:23.290 --> 00:00:29.100
But macOS is built on top of BSD Unix,
which is a very powerful server platform.

9
00:00:29.100 --> 00:00:32.080
So we can actually leverage
macOS as a server.

10
00:00:32.080 --> 00:00:36.330
And in fact, Apple has the macOS server
app available in the App Store that has

11
00:00:36.330 --> 00:00:38.890
a number of different
functions inside of it.

12
00:00:38.890 --> 00:00:43.000
And we've done this series over the years
for other platforms like El Capitan,

13
00:00:43.000 --> 00:00:47.630
and Mavericks, and even Sierra but
in High Sierra, macOS 10.13,

14
00:00:47.630 --> 00:00:52.640
there are significant changes coming
down from Apple on the server app.

15
00:00:52.640 --> 00:00:55.960
A lot of services are going away.

16
00:00:55.960 --> 00:00:58.030
Some services are staying,
some are going away,

17
00:00:58.030 --> 00:00:59.890
some are being replaced
by other functions.

18
00:00:59.890 --> 00:01:05.200
It's the biggest change to the macOS
server app in almost a decade.

19
00:01:05.200 --> 00:01:06.080
Really a long time.

20
00:01:06.080 --> 00:01:08.500
This is a really significant
amount of change.

21
00:01:08.500 --> 00:01:11.501
So in this series we're gonna be
taking a look at macOS server,

22
00:01:11.501 --> 00:01:15.410
how we can use our Mac as a server, how we
can leverage the services that Apple still

23
00:01:15.410 --> 00:01:19.206
provides in macOS server app, but also
take a look at some of the other functions

24
00:01:19.206 --> 00:01:22.292
that we can bring in to replace
the functionality that's gone.

25
00:01:22.292 --> 00:01:24.813
If you depend on the service
that's no longer supported,

26
00:01:24.813 --> 00:01:26.310
we need some kind of alternative.

27
00:01:26.310 --> 00:01:27.600
So, we're gonna be looking at that.

28
00:01:27.600 --> 00:01:32.130
So, if you've never used macOS server,
this series is gonna be a great place for

29
00:01:32.130 --> 00:01:34.350
you to jump and
get a chance to learn about it.

30
00:01:34.350 --> 00:01:37.104
If you are already neck deep in it and
you need to support it and

31
00:01:37.104 --> 00:01:40.290
now you're trying to figure out what
to do about services going away,

32
00:01:40.290 --> 00:01:42.460
we're gonna get a chance to tackle that,
too.

33
00:01:42.460 --> 00:01:45.496
So, we'll cover a lot of really
good stuff throughout this series.

34
00:01:45.496 --> 00:01:46.487
>> Important information and

35
00:01:46.487 --> 00:01:47.780
you've already touched on this but

36
00:01:47.780 --> 00:01:49.950
who's this show targeted towards?
>> Well,

37
00:01:49.950 --> 00:01:52.310
it's really targeted towards
system administrators.

38
00:01:52.310 --> 00:01:57.100
If you work in a business environment and
you're supporting macOS servers, this

39
00:01:57.100 --> 00:02:01.100
series is for you, because you need to be
sure to know what the future road map is.

40
00:02:01.100 --> 00:02:04.790
How to adapt your servers to support
Apple's future support model.

41
00:02:04.790 --> 00:02:08.220
You don't want to run software that's
not supported by Apple anymore.

42
00:02:08.220 --> 00:02:11.160
That's basically gonna leave you
up to all types of security risks.

43
00:02:11.160 --> 00:02:14.830
So if you're working in a business
supporting macOS servers,

44
00:02:14.830 --> 00:02:16.060
this course is for you.

45
00:02:16.060 --> 00:02:19.720
If you're not, but maybe that's what
you want to do, maybe you work in

46
00:02:19.720 --> 00:02:24.113
an environment where maybe you already
support Windows Servers, or Linux servers,

47
00:02:24.113 --> 00:02:27.529
and you just wanna entertain the idea
of using macOS as a server, or

48
00:02:27.529 --> 00:02:29.929
maybe you're just
a regular macOS home user.

49
00:02:29.929 --> 00:02:33.041
And you're thinking, boy, I'd like to set
up a little server here in my house, or

50
00:02:33.041 --> 00:02:34.140
just learn about it.

51
00:02:34.140 --> 00:02:35.370
Well, we're gonna cover that too.

52
00:02:35.370 --> 00:02:38.430
We're gonna start off from the very basics
and work up to the more advanced so

53
00:02:38.430 --> 00:02:40.670
it covers a lot of ground.

54
00:02:40.670 --> 00:02:44.260
Now I will tell you many
people are saying, hey,

55
00:02:44.260 --> 00:02:48.650
if Apple is shrinking down macOS
services as far as being a server,

56
00:02:48.650 --> 00:02:52.070
we need to move the services
over to Linux servers.

57
00:02:52.070 --> 00:02:55.620
If you want to do that,
this course is not exactly right for you.

58
00:02:55.620 --> 00:02:59.420
Instead, you should jump over and
check out our Linux Plus series.

59
00:02:59.420 --> 00:03:03.010
We cover how to set up Linux as a server,
get services loaded on it and

60
00:03:03.010 --> 00:03:04.420
get everything up and running there.

61
00:03:04.420 --> 00:03:06.980
But it's a different operating
system under the hood.

62
00:03:06.980 --> 00:03:10.580
I mentioned on macOS is running
BSD Unix under the hood.

63
00:03:10.580 --> 00:03:12.410
That is not the same as Linux.

64
00:03:12.410 --> 00:03:13.800
The commands are not all the same.

65
00:03:13.800 --> 00:03:14.910
The software is not the same.

66
00:03:14.910 --> 00:03:16.420
It is a different world.

67
00:03:16.420 --> 00:03:18.980
So if you're interested in
using Linux as your server,

68
00:03:18.980 --> 00:03:20.400
be sure to jump over to that show.

69
00:03:20.400 --> 00:03:23.100
But if you're interested in
learning about macOS as a server

70
00:03:23.100 --> 00:03:24.340
this is the right place to be.
>> So

71
00:03:24.340 --> 00:03:29.240
is there a certification involved?
>> There used to be, there isn't anymore.

72
00:03:29.240 --> 00:03:32.600
So Apple used to have the Apple
Certified Technical Coordinator, or

73
00:03:32.600 --> 00:03:35.920
ACTC certification,
which they've ended that certification.

74
00:03:35.920 --> 00:03:38.520
It's no longer available,
you can't take the test.

75
00:03:38.520 --> 00:03:42.000
And there used to be a course
called macOS Server Essentials,

76
00:03:42.000 --> 00:03:44.420
originally it was called
OS X Server Essentials.

77
00:03:44.420 --> 00:03:48.170
Well, since they have effectively gutted
the server app, there's no need for

78
00:03:48.170 --> 00:03:51.570
that server essential course anymore,
and so they've eliminated that one too.

79
00:03:51.570 --> 00:03:54.040
So there's no course,
there's no certification.

80
00:03:54.040 --> 00:03:55.310
It's all just gone.

81
00:03:55.310 --> 00:03:58.690
Well, the problem there is what happens
to all the people who have macOS

82
00:03:58.690 --> 00:04:00.040
servers out there?

83
00:04:00.040 --> 00:04:01.880
Kind of left to their own devices.

84
00:04:01.880 --> 00:04:02.910
Well, what do they do?

85
00:04:02.910 --> 00:04:07.150
And if you're in an all-Mac environment,
wouldn't it be nice to stand up a server

86
00:04:07.150 --> 00:04:10.400
and not have to bring in some other
operating system you're not familiar with?

87
00:04:10.400 --> 00:04:14.370
Well, you still can, there is still a
supported path that we can follow here to

88
00:04:14.370 --> 00:04:17.010
build up these servers, and
that's why this knowledge is relevant.

89
00:04:17.010 --> 00:04:19.180
So there's not a certification,

90
00:04:19.180 --> 00:04:22.340
but there is a real world need for
the skills that we're going to learn right

91
00:04:22.340 --> 00:04:25.015
here in this series.
>> So what topics are covered management

92
00:04:25.015 --> 00:04:27.907
mac OS servers 10.13?
>> All right we're going to cover a wide

93
00:04:27.907 --> 00:04:30.690
range of things, we're going to
start off with the super basics,

94
00:04:30.690 --> 00:04:33.050
we're going to see how to
install the macOS server app.

95
00:04:33.050 --> 00:04:35.478
Now, there's only a couple of
services left in it, right?

96
00:04:35.478 --> 00:04:37.104
But we still need to
know how to install it.

97
00:04:37.104 --> 00:04:40.030
And then we'll take a look at those
services that are still built in.

98
00:04:40.030 --> 00:04:43.476
It's really just two,
open directory and profile manager.

99
00:04:43.476 --> 00:04:46.974
So we'll take a look at those
two services, how they work, and

100
00:04:46.974 --> 00:04:49.551
how we can use those, and
see what they can do.

101
00:04:49.551 --> 00:04:54.047
Then we're gonna take a look at
some of the services that have been

102
00:04:54.047 --> 00:04:57.850
removed from the server app
that are now part of macOS.

103
00:04:57.850 --> 00:04:59.468
So, for example,
setting up a time machine server.

104
00:04:59.468 --> 00:05:01.380
You don't need the server app for
that anymore.

105
00:05:01.380 --> 00:05:02.828
It's just built into macOS.

106
00:05:02.828 --> 00:05:06.160
You can turn any Mac into
a Time Machine server.

107
00:05:06.160 --> 00:05:07.840
A cacheing server, same thing.

108
00:05:07.840 --> 00:05:09.470
A file server, same thing.

109
00:05:09.470 --> 00:05:10.930
That's all built in to the base OS.

110
00:05:10.930 --> 00:05:13.910
So, we'll take a look at those
functions and what those roles are.

111
00:05:13.910 --> 00:05:18.093
Now that's five different services right
there that are still fully supported by

112
00:05:18.093 --> 00:05:22.217
Apple, and still available right now and
for the forseeable future they've not

113
00:05:22.217 --> 00:05:24.597
announced end of life on any of those,
right?

114
00:05:24.597 --> 00:05:27.686
But then we're going to
look at all the others.

115
00:05:27.686 --> 00:05:31.500
There's a solid 10 other services that
have all been pruned off by Apple and

116
00:05:31.500 --> 00:05:33.740
these aren't services nobody cares about.

117
00:05:33.740 --> 00:05:35.110
Well, some of them are, right?

118
00:05:35.110 --> 00:05:36.590
Like there was a Wiki service.

119
00:05:36.590 --> 00:05:37.470
Nobody used that thing.

120
00:05:37.470 --> 00:05:38.810
It was just a web server.

121
00:05:38.810 --> 00:05:41.270
There's really no point in
having a service for it.

122
00:05:41.270 --> 00:05:43.020
Now it's gone.

123
00:05:43.020 --> 00:05:44.135
The VPN service.

124
00:05:44.135 --> 00:05:48.110
MacOS was never made a good VPN server so
people used firewalls for that.

125
00:05:48.110 --> 00:05:49.310
They use other options.

126
00:05:49.310 --> 00:05:51.170
So that makes sense those would go away.

127
00:05:51.170 --> 00:05:58.000
But their service is like DNS, DHCP,
file services though FTP or SFTP.

128
00:05:58.000 --> 00:06:02.820
Those are services that people use
every single day that are important.

129
00:06:02.820 --> 00:06:03.590
Net install.

130
00:06:03.590 --> 00:06:04.550
Net boot.

131
00:06:04.550 --> 00:06:06.050
Those are really important.

132
00:06:06.050 --> 00:06:09.530
If you're supporting a thousand Macs and
you need to pull an image out,

133
00:06:09.530 --> 00:06:10.632
those are important.

134
00:06:10.632 --> 00:06:13.999
Or those are all gone from macOS server,
right?

135
00:06:13.999 --> 00:06:18.159
But what a lot of people don't realize is
while Apple has removed the macOS server,

136
00:06:18.159 --> 00:06:20.966
they haven't completely
killed our support for them.

137
00:06:20.966 --> 00:06:24.700
That a lot of these are really just
Unix services in the background.

138
00:06:24.700 --> 00:06:26.760
And those unique services
are still there and

139
00:06:26.760 --> 00:06:30.210
still supported by Apple with
no end of life announced.

140
00:06:30.210 --> 00:06:33.910
Which means we're losing the graphical
user interface, the GUI, it's going away.

141
00:06:33.910 --> 00:06:37.600
But we still have the command line tools
in the background to be able to fire these

142
00:06:37.600 --> 00:06:41.730
services up, run them reliably and
continue doing it for years to come.

143
00:06:41.730 --> 00:06:43.040
That functionality is there.

144
00:06:43.040 --> 00:06:46.013
So, we're gonna take a look
the services that are still there, but

145
00:06:46.013 --> 00:06:48.952
from a command line perspective,
and see how it can manage those.

146
00:06:48.952 --> 00:06:51.577
And then for the one or
two that are totally gone,

147
00:06:51.577 --> 00:06:55.530
that are gone from the server app and
gone from the command line.

148
00:06:55.530 --> 00:06:57.580
Well, Apple has recommended replacements.

149
00:06:57.580 --> 00:07:00.033
They've said, here's an alternate
software you can use or

150
00:07:00.033 --> 00:07:02.644
an alternate solution you can use
to provide that same service.

151
00:07:02.644 --> 00:07:06.171
We're gonna take a look at those alternate
solutions and see what it takes to get

152
00:07:06.171 --> 00:07:09.310
that deployed, get it put in place,
and have it up and running.

153
00:07:09.310 --> 00:07:11.560
A great example of that is DNS.

154
00:07:11.560 --> 00:07:15.550
With DNS, macOS used to use
the bind service in the background.

155
00:07:15.550 --> 00:07:17.350
That's what was built
in to the server app.

156
00:07:17.350 --> 00:07:18.850
Well, Apple didn't make bind.

157
00:07:18.850 --> 00:07:22.520
Bind is made by a different organization,
ISE.

158
00:07:22.520 --> 00:07:26.702
And so, in that case, you can just go and
get bind from ISE and

159
00:07:26.702 --> 00:07:31.136
load it onto your server and
run it, and it works great, right?

160
00:07:31.136 --> 00:07:32.424
And it's still supported and

161
00:07:32.424 --> 00:07:35.268
it's actually several versions
ahead of what Apple is running.

162
00:07:35.268 --> 00:07:38.660
So in those cases we just need to know
who is the replacement, how do I get that

163
00:07:38.660 --> 00:07:41.897
loaded, how do I get it up and running and
now I've got the same service.

164
00:07:41.897 --> 00:07:44.853
That's all stuff that we're gonna be
looking at right here in the series.

165
00:07:44.853 --> 00:07:45.810
>> Well, thanks Don.

166
00:07:45.810 --> 00:07:49.549
And if managing macOS servers 10.13 sounds
like something you'd be interested in, and

167
00:07:49.549 --> 00:07:50.174
you should be.

168
00:07:50.174 --> 00:07:53.115
Make sure to watch all the episodes
in our course library.

169
00:07:53.115 --> 00:08:00.364
Thanks for
watching the binge-worth ITPro.TV.

170
00:08:00.364 --> 00:08:02.439
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don highlights the new features found in the macOS Server App v5.6. He discusses the services that are scheduled to be remove, and explains several options to replace any removed service.
episodes.title: What's New in macOS Server 5.6

episodes.description: In this episode, Don walks us through how to install the macOS Server App and provides a quick introduction to the various features inside the app. He also discusses the pre-requisites for installing as well as concerns when upgrading to a new version.
episodes.title: Installing macOS Server

episodes.description: In this episode Don demonstrates the various ways that you can remotely manage a machine running the macOS Server App. He demonstrates SSH, screen sharing and remotely executing the Server App itself.
episodes.title: Remote Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Don describes the three primary methods for monitoring a macOS Server to ensure it is on-line and healthy. He covers logging for past monitoring, statistics for real-time monitoring, and alerts for future monitoring.
episodes.title: Monitoring Performance

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to the Brew (Homebrew) package manager. He explains how the package manager functions, where the software comes from and how it functions. He also demonstrates how to install and update applications using Brew.
episodes.title: Managing Software with Brew

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to the Brew (Homebrew) package manager. He explains how the package manager functions, where the software comes from and how it functions. He also demonstrates how to install and update applications using Brew.
episodes.title: Managing Software with Brew Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don discusses how the Apple OpenDirectory authentication server functions. He then demonstrates how to install OpenDirectory and configure user accounts in preparation for binding clients.
episodes.title: Open Directory

episodes.description: In this episode Don demonstrates how to configure the Profile Manager to deploy configuration profiles to end user machines. He also shows some of the settings that can be configured.
episodes.title: Profile Manager

episodes.description: In this episode Don demonstrates how to configure the Profile Manager to deploy configuration profiles to end user machines. He also shows some of the settings that can be configured.
episodes.title: Profile Manager Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Don demonstrates how to configure the Profile Manager to deploy configuration profiles to end user machines. He also shows some of the settings that can be configured.
episodes.title: Profile Manager Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode Don explains the function and benefits of using a file server on your network. He then demonstrates how to configure the File Server role in macOS, which has moved out of the Server App and into the base operating system.
episodes.title: File Server

episodes.description: In this episode Don explains the function and benefits of using a Time Machine server on your network. He then demonstrates how to configure the Time Machine Server role in macOS, which has moved out of the Server App and into the base operating system.
episodes.title: Time Machine Server

episodes.description: In this episode Don explains the function and benefits of using a caching server on your network. He then demonstrates how to configure the Caching Server role in macOS, which has moved out of the Server App and into the base operating system.
episodes.title: Caching Server

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains what options are available now that Apple has end-of-lifed their DNS server. He then demonstrates how to disable Apple's DNS server and install ISC BIND. Fially, he demonstrates how to migrate zone files from Apple's DNS server into ISC BIND.
episodes.title: Replacing DNS with ISC-BIND

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how to configure new DNS zones in ISC BIND. He explains the format needed for DNS zone files and demonstrates how to use the named-checkzone utility to verify your file syntax and minimize downtime.
episodes.title: Replacing DNS with ISC-BIND Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains the options available to replace Apples DHCP server which has been discontinued. He explains why the ISC DHCP service is an ideal replacement as oppossed to bootpd. Finally, he demonstrates installing and configuring ISC DHCP.
episodes.title: Replacing DHCP with ISC-DHCP

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains the options available to replace Apple's Websites server which has been discontinued. He explains why the Apache webserver is an ideal replacement as oppossed to other options. Finally, he demonstrates installing and configuring Apache.
episodes.title: Replacing Websites with Apache

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains the options available to replace Apple's Websites server which has been discontinued. He explains why the Apache webserver is an ideal replacement as oppossed to other options. Finally, he demonstrates installing and configuring Apache.
episodes.title: Replacing Websites with Apache Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains the options available to replace Apple's Websites server which has been discontinued. He explains why the Apache webserver is an ideal replacement as opposed to other options. Finally, he demonstrates installing and configuring Apache.
episodes.title: Replacing Websites with Apache Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains the options available to replace Apple's Websites server which has been discontinued. He explains why the Apache webserver is an ideal replacement as opposed to other options. Finally, he demonstrates installing and configuring Apache.
episodes.title: Replacing Websites with Apache Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains the options available to replace Apple's Mail server which has been discontinued. He explains some of the options available to migrate the mail, contacts and calendar services.
episodes.title: Replacing Mail Server
